qas.question: What kind of softwoods often have significant differences in their earlywood and latewood?
Is latewood denser or less dense than earlywood?
Does strength come from the walls or cavities of wood cells?
Are the cell walls of earlywood thick or thin?
What general size are the cavities in the cells of very dense latewood?

context: In <a0_0>temperate<a0_0/> softwoods there often is a marked difference between latewood and earlywood. The latewood will be <a1_0>denser<a1_0/> than that formed early in the season. When examined under a microscope the cells of dense latewood are seen to be very thick-walled and with <a4_0>very small<a4_0/> cell cavities, while those formed first in the season have <a3_0>thin<a3_0/> walls and large cell cavities. The strength is in the <a2_0>walls<a2_0/>, not the cavities. Hence the greater the proportion of latewood the greater the density and strength. In choosing a piece of pine where strength or stiffness is the important consideration, the principal thing to observe is the comparative amounts of earlywood and latewood. The width of ring is not nearly so important as the proportion and nature of the latewood in the ring.
